reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: This game has been provided to me for free for review purposesOverviewBoss Constructor is a very unique and aspiring space game, where you build your own ship from modules, go on missions, explore galaxies and so on. It's an Alpha game, and I am amazed how well this game is being developed. It is packed with features, ideas, and it even has an in-build survey in the main menu so you can give your two cents on what should be changed, and when. Let's get into it!

The Pros:Truly a Sandbox - You don't need to follow a storyline, there are a dozen of game modes available, you can make and edit as many ships as you like, and the ship creation is very configurable! Except modules you have to research to unlock, everything in the game is available to you from minute 1!

UI OPTIONS!! - Wherever you go and can edit stuff, there is an accompanying right hand side menu with a lot of little buttons, toggles, and sliders. Everything is very detailed and really gives you the impression that you are in ultimate control.

Interesting Gamemodes - From the expected Randomly Generate Galaxy you must explore, we can go to other (fully scenario customisable) modes such as Huge Space Battle or AI Simulation and even Evolution!. Yup, you can sit and watch as the game simulates natural selection on your starting ship and calculates a numerous series of descendants! Take my word for it, there are many things to do when bored!

Update schedule - The game has very consistent and regularly released updates, all based on the survey you can complete in the main menu.
The Cons:Hard Controls - The ship operation is very difficult, in my opinion. Ship handling is hard, and lining up correctly to shoot an enemy is even more so. I wouldn't mind it that much, but it sort of distracts me from the other gameplay elements more that I'd like.

Graphics - I know this is an alpha indie game, so I won't be too harsh, the graphics are okay, but need a serious overhaul before I would accept them as final" version worthy. The UI could use a redesign as well. These are on the list of the dev
date: so we'll see how it turns out!\nConclusionThis is the most customizable space game I ever played before
recommended: and the constant updates really build up my confidence in the final release. For you

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Boss Constructor is like taking Spaz, Gratuitous space battles, and FTL and mashing them all together. Although it is still fairly early, the game promises to be the next great space shooter.

http://youtu.be/x3Q6X1vRecs
I found myself losing time in combat and losing even more time editing my space-fairing creations. The developer has already put in about 4 patches (after only one week) and when I did have some trouble with some CTD's, he immediately sent me the instructions to fix it.

So far, I like what I see, and I can't wait for more new ship parts to shove into the the evovler!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe game I have wanted all my childhood. Spaceship building with parts salvaged from other ships is a perfect mechanic in this game, and the objectives and combat feel fantastic. Controls are fully rebindable, and there are multiple different controlling modes (mouse, arrow keys, etc.). Developer is extremely responsive to community and is always talking advice, even going as far as having in game surveys on controversial additions and decisions. The main gamemode is to explore a randomly generated galaxy, but there are other gamemodes such as a deathmatch, endless mode, and hopefully an upcoming campaign. Completely worth the asking price!
voteText: 18 of 20 people (90%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As the title suggests this game is focused on construction, could easily spend hours completely customizing your ships in a very lego-like manner. Physics of space play a large role but after tinkering around for a while it's easy to grasp the basic concepts. Only left up to your imagination what you come up with.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xHRFjb4INt4
Early access doesn't contain the singleplayer story, but there are randomized galaxies and expedition modes which are a bunch of fun alone. Basically you fly around the galaxies clearing out each sector, picking up new items from enemies destroyed, black holes and space anomalies in general. Completing a sector will give you the ability to use the collected pieces to repair/upgrade/enhance your spaceships.

Should provide many hours of fun for fans of exploration/construction games.
Can't wait to see how the full storymode plays out. :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Every now and then a game comes along  where the actual menu reflects just how cool and polished a game is going to be.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WRnOByg5Ytg
This is one of those games where you instinctively know you are in for a treat. And boy is it a treat. Boss Constructor is a game about building and flying your own spaceships. The core feature of the game is its editor which allows you to assemble your own ships based on a number of components. At first glance this concept might look confusing and hard but it's as easy as lego bricks to master. A superb game - Highly Recommended!

What a Fantastic game!   If this seems like the sort of game you might be interested in I would highly suggest you pick it up.

Still in Early Access but CONSTANTLY updated, every time I log into Steam there seems to be a small patch tweaking/fixing things and then every Sunday for a while now there is the content patch from the Sunday twitch coding session the developer does.

One of the problems with early access is you are not sure if the game is going to ever be finished or updated at all.  The amount of features in this game constantly grows with the dedicated developer and is well worth it!

Can't recommend enough, but I can try!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAwesome and Incredibly addictive little game. Lots of fun and potential in it for any dignified space shooting ship assembling geekster fan (like me self). For an Early Access game I have to say it's very well executed. Every thing runs smoothly and properly and apart from some labels and feedbak info still missing here and there it is apparent that a lot of care was put into it. It's a lot of fun assembling the amorphous ships and testing them in the 'field' and the set of parts available is quite enjoyable. It should be a very decent and wide scoped game once it leaves alpha/beta stage and comes out into a full fledged game. As of now, even while in Early Access, it is already very playable and worth every cent (and surely hours of fun).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

GOOD:
+ building my own ships in non-explore mode, improvising, trying them out in fun dog fights

+ in explore mode: improvising small ships with limited resources. Strong loot motivation to collect modules shot down enemy ships!

+ big variety of enemy ships, also a small space station, ship-factory, mine fields. Even automated evolution of enemy ships. (don't know whether this is used in explore mode though)

+ custom key binding. And very clever auto-combination of which thruster is fired for which movement direction (can be overriden) no matter how you build your ship. (limited use for assymetric ships though)

+ during the last 2 months: new patches keep coming. Developer's response to bugs and feature whishes very impressive.

+ meaningful limitations to concentrate on the important parts: a) 2D, not 3D; b) limited maximum ship speed; c) ships get slower pretty fast if thrusters are not fired; d) battle field is not too big

BAD:

- for me, nothing. Of course I miss many things, but this is early access, the game is not finished yet. Still fun to play!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Out of all the games I've gotten on Steam so far, this is the first one I've felt like writing a review for, mainly because I see a lot of potential in this one and hope for it to succeed. So keep in mind this is my first review and it is for an Early Access game.

Starting Off
This game is a sandbox through and through, focusing obviously on the construction of a customized ship and then allowing you to test it out within various game modes from a full campaign of sorts where you establish yourself with different factions that each have their focus on research types, a survival mode, random missions and more to come I am sure. Sure, there is no story, save a generic themed enemy that apparently is a threat for some reason, but let's admit that isn't what people play sandbox games for.

There is already plenty of modules for making the ship function the way you like to play. Want a gunship? Make it happen. Want a ship that has more versatility in tools and tech? Do it. However, at the current point in the game, it feels like there is very limited uses for many of the different techs already available, and in time I hope to see more reasons and uses for it all.

Graphically speaking, it's nothing impressive, but there's plenty of particle effects to keep things flashy enough to keep my attention. I still get the inner satisfaction when I destroy enemy ships to say the least, and the effects of the weapons and other modules feels appropriate for what they are/do. The music does its job at setting the feel for the missions and stuff, but tends to get a little repetitive after awhile and I have begun muting the music to play my own during my long sit down sessions with this game (three in total so far).

Positives    Exceptional Ship Customization
Basic, But Helpful Tutorial (With exception of the negative below)
Fully Rebindable Controls & Controller Support
A Developer Who Appears Interested In Feedback
Numerous Modes of Play With Challenge For All
Negatives    Rebindable Controls Do Not Fix Difficult Maneuvering
Moderate Learning Curve (Knowing which faction to help in the procedurally generated galaxy, and how it applies to your research is something I am still figuring out... could be helpful to explain that in the tutorial.)
Neutral Factors (Things I believe will probably get better as development continues)
Limited Mission Variety (Currently they could get repetitive for those who prefer variations)
Few Reasons to Use Specific Module Types (This might be a personal preference thing)
Occasional Bugs (To be expected with Early Access)
More Control Options than Buttons on Controllers (I am sure the expected interface with the game is via keyboard and mouse, but the use of a controller is a very nice option when wanting to play casually, and it feels limited when you have to choose what abilities you want to have access to if using the controller.)
Assessment
Overall this is a very entertaining experience for me, as I keep spending time trying to tweak my ships to be more streamlined, or trying to upgrade my modules. For an Early Access title, this one is one of few I have felt is worth the asking price, though I happened to find it on sale and became my replacement for another game since I can't play (and have chosen not to) Galactic Civilizations 3. With the level of customization, replayability due to a variety of game types, and the fact that the developer seems to be actively engaged with the playing community and offering frequent updates, I suggest you take a look at this game if it happens to be your cup of tea. Being still in development, it has plenty of potential to become a gem in my library.

Personal Verdict  8.5 / 10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBoss Constructor is a neat little game in active development.  I had a problem getting it to run, and the dev had a patch to fix my issue within hours.  Unheard of.  Gameplay is solid and engaging, and the incentives to play another map are already strong.  I can't wait to see how this game shapes up in the coming months.  If you like space shootemups and you like builders, I strongly recommend giving this game a shot.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is quite unique and a very interesting style of game play.

I am very much enjoying playing this game and I'm sure that it will keep me playing for quite some time to come.  I congratulate the developer on the direction that he is taking this game and recommend it to anyone who loves to build and fiddle with bits and pieces to create an interesting toy to play with.

The dev is continually updating the game and offerring us more playthings.  He responds readily to comments and is most helpful.  All of his updates so far have been good ones.

My only complaint is that at this time it is lacking a manual to give the beginner some undertanding of how the variousl components of the game system work.  However with some experimentation it has finally fallen into place and the further that I understand it, the better it gets.

It is worth the price when compring it to some of my recent purchases online.  You should enjoy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really like the concept, but I didn't enjoy this game. I didn't play long, but long enough to realize most of my playtime was frustrating because I was fighting the user interface and control scheme. I also couldn't figure out how to purchase new weapons/solar panels for my ship. I couldn't tell which things persist between missions and which don't. When you load, it's where you left off before starting the mission, but apparently when you edit your ship, that's saved outside of missions...I don't know. Very confusing. The ship building UI is a jumbled mess of buttons, and I can't figure anything out.

This game needs to be simplified. It feels needlessly complex, almost like it's a stream of development/design conciousness. The survey pops up in your face asking what kinds of things should be improved before you've even played the tutorial. Also, the control scheme feels really clunky, at least for keyboard/mouse (my preferred controllers).

Neat idea, but I can't recommend this game in its current state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I want to like this game, I really really do. The premise is enticing, the bones are... present; but the execution falls flat, even for an early access game. The control scheme and UI are frustrating on a fundamental level, and the absolute lack of control and understanding given to the player renders the game nigh unplayable.

Bugs are present as well, and in my fraction of an hour of playtime, I encontered invisible ships, weapons, and projectiles. my weapons would (nearly always) stop firing, or cease to work entirely. Ireally  wanted to sink in more time before writing this review to give the game a fair shot - but honestly, I couldn't bring myself to; and that's a resounding testament to the game's playability.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It looks like its deep and its fun but its not. Its complicated and boring and very 2D. From what I could see most maps have an enemy to destroy and some asteroids to blow up and some space mines. That's it. You just do the same things over and over. You can put your engines here or there and it affects the whole spinning out of control issue. If you'd like you can spend a lot of time trying to figure out things that should be pretty simple or at least explained.

The physics are wrong. No space ship should handle this bad.
Exploring areas. From time to time you need to explore an area. That means you have to move your ship near some rectangles. They'll disappear. Done! Does that sound like fun? It isn't.

Can I build an interesting ship? you might ask. No. Seems like you should be able to build an interesting ship like lets say something similar to one of the big capital ships in Sins of Solar Empire that has many functions. That would be interesting but as far as I can see you can't build anything like that. There are some extraordinary people on the internet. I've seen them at work on Besiege and they can create almost anything of enormous complexity. Maybe they can do something incredible with Boss Constructor but not me. I didn't see much possibility and isn't that what I'm paying for? The game is supposed to make me feel like I can, with my normal abilities create something marvelous using their easy to understand tools. They have totally failed because I cannot create marvelous things and their tools are not easy to understand.

Let me compare it to a game that is fun - Lunar Flight. In Lunar Flight you have some sophisticated navigational devices to get you to a floating sphere that needs to be researched". Once you get there you have to use your piloting skills to float within the sphere while the sphere is being researched. This requires skill
date: which you can learn with some diligence. The result is a satisfying 3D experience because the maps in Lunar flight look fantastic compared to any game whereas the maps in Boss Constructor look like crap and the physics feel so right.\n\nHave you ever worked on a monitor that is reflecting things from the background into your eyes? Well
recommended:
that's what every map in Boss Constructor looks like. The planets in the background look like an annoying reflection on your monitor. On a positive note I think I did read that you can turn off backgrounds.

I could say more but...
To summarize - Boss Constructor as it is now

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just very quickly for now:
- great 2D space shooter with emphasis on building your own ship (boss) module by module
- caring developer with lightning fast response (next day patch)
- frequent patches bringing lots of new and improved stuff

In comparison with Reassembly:
- grid based ship editor (simpler but less flexible)
- battles occur on separate randomly generated maps (as opposed to Reassembly's huge continuous ecosystem)
- ship size is currently rather limited, both by ship editor and by performance I reckon, but impressive beats of doom can be had
- broken modules remain broken until the end of battle, forcing the player to adapt to new ship behavior and build their ship to survive these brutal scenarios - this rewards good engineering!


I love it already and I have high hopes it's gonna get much better as it has potential to be as unique as Reassembly or SPAZ with its own mix of space shooting/engineering goodness.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let's go over the good and the bad.

1. This game is NOT an open-space game. You have to play missions and skirmishes to unlock parts, which allow you to build bigger and better ships that use those parts so you can acquire even more parts in said missions.

2. There are really only two levels of difficulty. REALLY bloody bleeding edge hard, and super stupid easy where you have to actually try to lose in order to lose. For example, the types of enemies you face will either be teeny ships that pose zero threat to you, or really big ships that can blast you with all kinds of firepower. And inside those, there are only two types of AI. The first type is simple 'shoot at player and try to kill them AI
date: and the second is the impossibly hard to fight "RAM PLAYER WITH EVERYTHING WE'VE GOT AND DON'T STOP RAMMING UNTIL ONE OF US IS DEAD". When you find a big ship utilizing ramming behavior
recommended: you pretty much always lose.\n\n3. The ship building on this game is really really fun. However

Early Access Review

I'm not sure about the long term, but for what i've played Boss Constructor is very enjoyable and has many different settings to try with all the different modules to build your ship with.

Also, the developper seems to be trusty and serious, as for one year there was at least one update every week, from bug fix to content and balance.

I'd say, if you like this kind of game, it's a game for you. If you don't, try it anyway, you may discover something new you like.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

8.5/10  It has potential to be a great 2D space game.

Pros

- beautiful atmosphere and visual effects (after turning off tactical grid in maps)
Although ships' design look meh, I never thought that in-game graphic would looks much much better than what I see in YouTube videos
I guess it's because they didn't turn off the grid during gameplay.

- space looks lively, you can see AI ships do different things in space.

- have good amount of contents, and a lot of adjustable options

- editing ships is easy and fun like the way I enjoy in GalCiv3

Cons

- clunky UI, player can't access options menu while playing in a mission. Options are available in main menu only.
- cannot restart mission unless you choose to go back to the main menu

-  lack of continuity feeling in Exploration mode. I feel like I'm just going through a number of missions instead of exploring space. My actions doesn't effect anything to the game world.

I know that Story Mode will comes soon and it will add some continuity feeling.
but I'm not sure if the story mode would have freedom complexity as much as FTL or Convoy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Beautiful, just beautiful.

I currently have a few indie games I'm playing and enjoying.
But this game... RWR or this.

I find more potential, and a significant amount more fun (even in current state), in this game than say... Reassembly.

I find the weapons and combat very diverse in this current state, and the amount of strategies I can think of are many.
You have choices that You make in combat that may very well make or break Your mission/exploration based on knowing when to retreat so that You don't lose say, all the thrusters/jets on one side of the ship.

With the potential this game has, I highly recommend purchasing this game, and supporting it's development.  I don't see how it doesn't have a future as a defining game in this genre.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I was a kid, my friends and I used to play what we called Lego Ships. We basically built spaceships out of Legos, using very loosely defined rules as to what piece did what (Lego-guy-legs with the tops pointed forward were cannons, lights were phasers/lasers, and anything proturding off the back was a thruster), and we'd imagine characters and stories to go with our creations. Our method of fighting was to take our finger and jam it into the other guy's ship, knocking what pieces off that we could. In hindsight, that's not the worst way that one could simulate fighting in space, I guess.

Despite your initial primary weapon being space-fireballs (what?), Boss Constructor feels a bit like Lego Ships made into a video game. You cobble together a ship with what you can find, and then you poke the crap out of enemies until stuff falls off. And then you take said stuff and put it on your ship to make it better.

As it stands right now, the game is entertaining, if shallow. It absolutely does nothing to justify the RPG tag, so certainly don't buy it expecting a story, because if it's going to have one, it's not there yet. It's neat that the developer is asking people to vote on things like modules and asking for ideas for missions, though I do wonder if that doesn't mean the developer's running out of ideas. The game has been on Steam as an Early Access for over a year, after all, though I certainly have not been involved long enough to know what state the game was in when it was first made available.

Whatever you do, don't buy this game expecting a release-quality experience. It's definitely not that. It's stable enough to play (three CTDs in 15 hours isn't bad for early access), and looks to be a great platform on which to build a really good game, but it's far from finished.

Music is limited, sound effects are at least decent, and your ship handles like a big, complicated version of the ship you use in Asteroids. If you want maneuverability, or the ability to reverse, or any kind of speed, you have to place thrusters, pointed in the right direction, and enough to counter the weight of your ship. Your ship will continue indefinitely until you fire thrusters pointing the other direction to stop you. It's not nearly so complicated or hard to control as it could be, though, and the controls strike a very, very good balance between realism and playability.

I've already got access to nearly every possible module, and everything from here on out seems to be just more punishing versions of what I've already done. I'm disappointed that there are so few modules that are rarer and higher tech, meaning smaller, lighter versions of what you need. I kind of thought that sort of progression was a given in a spaceship building type of game. That's not to say that the concept is absent -- just lacking.

I also think the ship construction (which is definitely the core of the game) would benefit from having two or three layers so that you're not so limited in your design by the game being strictly two-dimensional. For instance, the only way to change the direction of a weapon is to put it on an auto-aim joint. As of now, there is no way to put a weapon between but below or above your thrusters, or armor, or anything else, forcing you to either extend the weapon further out than every other part of the ship, or risk (guarantee, really) shooting yourself if an enemy ends up beside you since your weapon will automatically turn to point at it, regardless of what part of your ship is in the way.

Everything shield related is pretty goofy as well. You either have this orbiting projectile-blocking thing that will get between you and enemies (meaning you'll always hit it when you shoot) or some peacock-feather-looking extensions that also block your own fire. Maybe the developer just really likes the idea of parts flying off of the ships and, honestly, so do I, but I'm not sure how I'm supposed to go about fighting anything remotely hard when I can't shield my weapons.

However, if you enjoy the idea of slapping parts off of other spaceships using space-arc-welders and space-fireball-launchers, then stealing those parts because apparently they're really durable but not connected very well, then I don't know of a better game for you. And, hopefully, there's a lot more to come.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Been looking for this style of game for a while and this one seems to fit the bill nicely. Some really nice depth, without being overly confusing (although some parts are a little confusing on occasion) the ship building is very intuitive and a lot of fun and exploring and fighting is tense and rewarding.

At first I thought it was a little bit expensive for a game of this type but I feel like Im getting value for money due to the depth of the game and the fact it will be expanded. Look forward to seeing this game develop, and for a game in Alpha stages it has been playing smoothly with nothing significantly going wrong or encountering any bugs. Overall I am happy with this game and will play it. Would recommend to anyone looking for this style of game who is willing to take a punt on an early access title.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR: This game is like a way kick @ss HD / More Serious FTL: Faster Than Light 9/10.

So at first the game is a little confusing if you're not sure exactly sure what mode to pick or how to customize your ship. Games with a high learning curve tend to be this way, but once you get past the difficulty of winging your way through a couple galaxies (took me 6 to finally GET it) you'll find it's a hell of a lot of fun!

If you pick exploration mode-
No,
Pick exploration mode or the tutorial, the tutorial helps with basic commands but you really gotta get in there to know it all. You get to choose from a variety of 6 default ships and a bonus" which adds additional ship parts to customize with at the start. You pick your ship and your bonus and BEFORE YOU DO ANYTHING! click the 'edit ship / repair ship' button in the bottom right. From here you click and drag parts from the drop menu's onto your default ship or you can mix it all up or scrap the whole thing and start from scratch! All of the features work
date: this is an Early Access game done RIGHT. I can't wait to see what new things they add next.\n\nOnce you've got a ship all powered and with guns or whatever click on a sector in the galaxy and pay attention to your Primary and Secondary objectives. You don't have to complete them
recommended: but if you want to advance to the other sectors then you must at least complete the Primary objective. They reward you with all kinds of parts to play around with and honestly
hoursPlayed: you'll just have to see the rest for yourself :)"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNot sure why Steam is not calculating my time correctly but I have played over ten hours of this game for starters. This game is very unique and has quite a learning curve. As you explore the map you encounter varied entities including friendlies and enemies. You always have the option to fight or flee, and your ship handling reflects its current damage. As you complete missions and defeat enemies, you collect parts and blueprints to customize your ship (of which you can build from scratch or select a premade). All in all for an Early Access Game I would say that this is right on par with where it should be in this stage of development. I am very likely to continue playing and extremely excited to see where this is going to go. I would say give it a try it definately fits into its own little niche!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game is still clearly early access and not everything fully works and could still use quite a lot more polish, but it's entirely playable and enjoyable as-is and 100% worth an Early Access purchase if you enjoy the genre.

The genetic algorithm mode is particularly neat even if it doesn't work very well. Not really something you see often and I dig that even if it completely freezes my computer like I dunno, 9 times out of 10?

Exploration mode is the heart of the game and while it can be a really rough start if you pick a bad starter ship (with no real guidance say, that it's going to be super-hard mode since, oh hey, you just configured a ship with no weapons of any kind) overall, if you make it past the first round or two, it gets really fun. You constantly get to exercise your creativity as new modules and module varients become available to you. I'd say AI is only a challenge if you're outnumbered and surrounded, but that definitely happens and when it does, you may very well have a truly challenging fight on your hands. Most of the time, with any kind of decent tactics to control engagements and a good ship design, fights are pretty easy though. But that also makes it easier to become complacent and get totally surprised when a tactical situation changes suddenly and your gun arcs can't hit something that's picking away at your engines. Engines matter a lot in this game and once a couple are gone, you are all but hosed. I really like having a more tactical shoot-em-up, and I found most of the game design decisions here to result in pretty cool gameplay.

My biggest criticism of the game, if I had any would be that the non-combat missions can get a little tedious after you get the same one too many times in a row.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Boss Constructor combines a lot of elements from various games and creates a really decent title that I would whole heartedly recommend to everyone.

In essense this game is:
-part FTL (random level progression and instadeath)
-part ship builder (scavenge parts from destroyed ships and attach to yours)
-part space trading game (occasional random ore and trader to buy/sell stuff)
-part intense 2d battle simulation with Netwonian physics

It's still in early beta, but already has a very stable build with tons of variety and gameplay. Can't wait for the final release!

Check the video review for more info:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rBW96MhxJAw

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: I was given a free copy of this game for review purposes.

For a game in Early Access, it has cross-platform support, runs incredibly well (except in 100 ship battles), and has only a few UI bugs, which deserves applause.

Combat [h1/]

The game is 2-D, and you manuever your ship around with the left and right keys, then fire them with up and down. This also means that you must point your ship at an enemy in order to fire your weapons, which takes a lot of skill. The enemy AI is so good it feels like you are fighting a player, since they will navigate around obstacles and take care to aim, rather than just spam.

This game mechanic gives skilled pilots a huge advantage with smaller ships, as they can deal out damage before a larger ship has even brought its weapons to bear.

By far this is the only game I have seen where skill is the ulitmate decidin factor in a fight.

Building [h1/]

By defeating enemies and destroying stuff, modules are dropped. You can use these to aid in construction, and some have stats that can be positive or negative, depenidng on its quality.

The more modules a ship has, the larger its mass, and therefore it is less manueverable and requires more power.

Exploration [h1/]

To start exploring, generate a galaxy, and you will be able to progress through randomly generated levels with objectives, such as destroying stations and/or ships in the area, or collecting stranded escape pods.

Graphics [h1/]

The game is very well-optimized, and you could run it wihout problems on a potato.

The backgrounds are breathtaking space art, which fit well with the FTL - like artstyle for everything else, but higher-res.

Misc. [h1/]

No DLC.

Full Steam Workshop support for sharing ships.

Achievements.

Very active developers (look at the update log!)

Nice sound effects and space-y music.

Must buy if you love anything similar to FTL.
